awd_titl_txt: Gatekeepers to Broadening Participation in Engineering: Investigating variation across high schools comparing who could go versus who does go into engineering
awd_abstract_narration:
Engineering is one of the fastest-growing sectors of the U.S. economy. However, there is a shortage of diverse engineers and scientists in this sector. This research investigation is designed to equip engineering education researchers and other important stakeholders with the knowledge and understanding of how school stakeholders can be better positioned and/or trained to support a more diverse population of students who choose to enroll in postsecondary engineering programs. By focusing on the high school level, the investigators will pinpoint how educational inequalities (as they relate to access to school resources and the role and preparedness of high school counselors and teachers in helping students choose engineering programs) will contribute to academically capable students' decisions to major or not major in engineering, especially among underrepresented student populations. This research project is both timely and potentially impactful in helping the broader engineering community identify the structural barriers that students often experience in different high schools across the state of Virginia and how these barriers may influence underrepresented students' decisions to major or not major in engineering, even when they possess the academic profile to do so. The project also has immense potential to render important findings applicable to key engineering and non-engineering stakeholders in Virginia and beyond. 

Using a mixed-method research design, data collections were organized into various phases: examining quantitative data from the Virginia Longitudinal Data System (VLDS) to explore high school and college enrollment student records for every Virginia high school student; conducting in-depth qualitative interviews of key school stakeholders (e.g., teachers, school counselors, etc.) at select high schools; collecting student survey data at the same select high schools to determine alignment between what interviewees say are influences versus what students say drive them toward or away from engineering; and collecting survey data from key stakeholders to complement the qualitative interview data. By collecting both quantitative and qualitative data, the research investigation will provide important answers to major broadening participation in engineering questions. Through workshops, policy briefs, K-12 academic conferences, and connections with specific schools selected as case studies, the investigators outlined a strong plan to share findings with K-12 practitioners and policymakers.
org_div_long_name: Division of Engineering Education and Centers

inst.inst_name: Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University

por.por_cntn:
Enrollment in engineering and computer science postsecondary degree programs and careers is not equally distributed across all segments of the population, despite continued investments and efforts to address this gap. This study aimed to better understand the transition from high school into enrollment in postsecondary engineering and computer science bachelor’s programs, either directly from high school or via the transfer pathway from a community college. We tracked (anonymous) individual students from Virginia public high schools into postsecondary enrollment (N=685,429 students, high school graduating years 2007-2014) using data from the Virginia Longitudinal Data System (VLDS). The VLDS connects student-level administrative data from the Department of Education (PK-12) to postsecondary records from the State Council of Higher Education for Virginia. To better understand or “unpack” why certain schools and divisions yield different engineering enrollment rates, we explored student data in VLDS, such as high school course taking, and also interviewed administrators, school counselors, and teachers from five purposefully sampled regional sites across Virginia. Our results shed light on demographic and school-based patterns that could be used to (a) guide conversations around local and state policy; and (b) increase and broaden enrollment in engineering in Virginia. In addition to disseminating results via journal articles and academic conference presentations, we prepared findings for practitioner-oriented workshops as well as via summary and school-/institution-specific data tailored to every public high school, school division office, four-year college and university, and community college in Virginia. Select findings include the following:


Virginia mirrors national trends with uneven demographic representation in engineering and computer science. Dramatically more males (11.5% vs. 2.3% female) in Virginia enrolled in a four-year engineering program at some point in their postsecondary educational careers across Virginia’s high schools.  Historically underrepresented racial minority groups (URM) in engineering – principally African American and Latinx students – remained quite underrepresented as well; URM males enrolled at much higher rates than URM females.  However, white and Asian (i.e., non-URM) males who were economically disadvantaged in their senior year of high school (indexed by a composite eligibility for benefit programs) proportionately enrolled more frequently in engineering compared to other historically marginalized demographic groups within the field. 


Locality and school postsecondary rates relate to engineering enrollment rates.  Although community socioeconomic status (indexed by zip-code median income and percent bachelor’s degrees) in which schools are embedded was moderately associated with engineering enrollment rates, the strongest predictor was the overall four-year college-going rate for a given high school. When high schools sent more students to four-year colleges, a greater proportion of those four-year college students enrolled in engineering. Together, these two factors accounted for half of the variability in engineering enrollment rates. 


Ten percent of future engineering students do not take calculus in high school. Most future four-year college engineering students show an advanced-math heavy pattern. However, the fact that 10 percent of future engineering students did not take calculus in high school suggests advanced math course taking itself may not be a clear determinant of a future in engineering, especially when considering a range of postsecondary institutions. 


Regional culture influences how school personnel guide students regarding engineering.  Our findings suggest that regional cultures can play a significant role in influencing how socializers (i.e., teachers, school counselors, etc.) influence students’ postsecondary pathways. Regional cultures may open or limit access to certain pathways for students. This finding suggests that “one-size-fit-all” solutions may not be appropriate in addressing how to broaden participation in engineering, as schools have distinct and unique ecosystems and cultures. Students may be more receptive to messages about engineering that are situated within local contexts.  


Specialized courses and programs have promise but also important nuances. First, our exploratory analysis of engineering-focused CTE courses illuminated variation across Virginia in how these courses are described, packaged, and offered to students. Enrollment in engineering-focused CTE courses related to subsequent enrollment in engineering and computer science bachelor’s programs; however, the story regarding engineering-focused CTE courses is quite nuanced and varied across Virginia. There is no consistent way of describing and packaging engineering-focused CTE courses into larger pathways, not all engineering-focused CTE courses have the same relationships with postsecondary outcomes, and the extent to which students had access to engineering-focused CTE courses varies as a function of school districts’ resource bases. Second, we also examined Virginia’s STEM Academies (i.e., a career academy program). After controlling for potential self-selection through propensity score matching, Academy students who enrolled in postsecondary schools were twice as likely to enroll in a STEM major than students in a matched sample of non-Academy participants. This effect was greater for female students than for male students, and we also observed stronger relationships for Black and Asian students, which has important implications for fields that have been trying to broaden participation for decades.

 


Last Modified: 04/29/2022
Modified by: David Knight
